fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Sheaves in geometry and logic
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: @book{maclane-moerdijk-1994, title = {Sheaves in Geometry and Logic: A First Introduction to Topos Theory}, author = {MacLane, S. and Moerdijk, I.}, isbn = {9781461209270}, doi = {10.1007/978-1-4612-0927-0} lccn = {91033709}, series = {Universitext}, url = {https://books.google.com/books?id=LZWLBAAAQBAJ}, year = {1994}, publisher = {Springer New York}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We dedicate this book to the memory of J. Frank Adams. His clear insights have inspired many mathematicians, including both of us. In January 1989, when the first draft of our book had been completed, we heard the sad news of his untimely death. This has cast a shadow on our subsequent work. Our views of topos theory, as presented here, have been shaped by continued study, by conferences, and by many personal contacts with friends and colleagues-including especially O. Bruno, P. Freyd, J.M.E. Hyland, P.T. Johnstone, A. Joyal, A. Kock, F.W. Lawvere, G.E. Reyes, R Solovay, R Swan, RW. Thomason, M. Tierney, and G.C. Wraith. Our presentation combines ideas and results from these people and from many others, but we have not endeavored to specify the various original sources. Moreover, a number of people have assisted in our work by pro viding helpful comments on portions of the manuscript. In this respect, we extend our hearty thanks in particular to P. Corazza, K. Edwards, J. Greenlees, G. Janelidze, G. Lewis, and S. Schanuel.
Let C be a category so that any cospan has a cocone (i.e., C satisfies the right Ore condition). Then the atomic topology on C is the Grothendieck topology such that all nonempty sieves are covering.

The dense topology on a category C is the Grothendieck topology where a sieve S on x is covering if and only if, for every y\xrightarrow {f} x, there exists a z\xrightarrow {g} y such that the composite is in S.
The join topology on a complete Heyting algebra is the Grothendieck topology generated by the basis of families \{x_i\leq x\} such that \bigvee x_i = x.

Let P be a presheaf and S a sieve on x. Regarding S as a subfunctor of C(-, x), a matching family of P for S is just a natural transformation S\to P. Explicitly, a matching family assigns, to each y\xrightarrow {f} x in S, an element p_f\in P. This data must be compatible with restriction via P, in that p_f|_g = p_{fg} for all z\xrightarrow {g} y.
The maximal sieve on an object x is the sieve consisting of all arrows with codomain x; equivalently, the sieve associated to the contravariant hom-functor.
A presheaf C^\text {op}\xrightarrow {P} Set on a site is a sheaf if, for all objects x and covering families S, each natural transformation S\xrightarrow {\alpha } P lifts uniquely to C(-, x):
The trivial topology on a category C is the Grothendieck topology where the only covering sieve is the maximal sieve.
The topology generated by K is the Grothendieck topology wherein a sieve S covers an object x if and only if T\subseteq S for some T\in K(x).

Equivalently, say that a sieve S covers a map y\xrightarrow {f} x if the
pullback f^*S covers y. Then the axioms state: 
if f\in  S, then S covers f;
  
if S covers f, then it covers fg for any g where the
  composition makes sense;
  
if S covers f and T covers each g\in  S, then T covers
  f.
A category equipped with a Grothendieck topology is called a site.
In the backwards direction, if J satisfies the map axioms, then letting f = 1_x shows that it satisfies the object axioms.
In the forwards direction, let J satisfy the object axioms. Then:

fr:ul.fr:li: For any sieve S on x and any f\in S, f^*S covers the domain of f by the stability axiom, so S covers f.
If S covers f, then f^*S covers the domain of f, so that by stability g^*f^*S covers the domain of g.

If S covers y\xrightarrow {f} x and T covers each g\in S, then f^*S covers the y, while for each g\in S, g^*T covers the domain of g. Now by transitivity, T covers x, so that by stability, T covers f.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let C have pullbacks, and let y\xrightarrow {f} x be any map. Then there is a base change functor C/x\xrightarrow {f^*} C/y between over categories acting by pullback.

It remains to show the desired adjunction. Since 1_y is terminal in C/y, a map n\to \Pi _f m in C/y induces, again by the universal property of the pullback, a unique map n\to \left [c\xrightarrow {m} x\xrightarrow {f} y^{(x\xrightarrow {f} y)}\right ] whose post-composition with m is the identity 1_f. Taking the transpose yields a map \left [f\times n\right ]\xrightarrow {g^\dag } \left [c\xrightarrow {m}x\xrightarrow {f} y\right ]. However, the product in C/y is exactly the pullback in C, so that (since mg = 1_x), this is equivalently a map f^*n\to m in C/x.
Let S be a sieve on x\in C and y\xrightarrow {f} x any map. Then the pullback sieve f^*S consists of those z\xrightarrow {g} y in C such that z\xrightarrow {g}y\xrightarrow {f} x\in S.

fr:title.text: Heyting algebras are Boolean iff they satisfy double negation elimination

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Heyting algebras are Boolean iff they satisfy double negation elimination

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A Heyting algebra is boolean if and only if it satisfies double negation elimination: \lnot \lnot x = x.

fr:title.text: Every complete lattice is a Heyting algebra

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Every complete lattice is a Heyting algebra

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Every complete distributive lattice is a Heyting algebra with the implication x\Rightarrow y := \bigvee \{z : z\wedge x\leq y\}.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This comes from the general adjoint functor theorem.

fr:title.text: Every Boolean algebra is a Heyting algebra

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Every Boolean algebra is a Heyting algebra

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Every Boolean algebra is a Heyting algebra with the implication x\Rightarrow y := \lnot x\vee y.
In a Heyting algebra, the negation of an element x is \lnot x := x \Rightarrow 0.

fr:title.text: Presheaf categories are complete and cocomplete

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Presheaf categories are complete and cocomplete

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Every presheaf category is complete and cocomplete, with limits and colimits computed as in Set.
Limits and colimits are computed pointwise and Set is complete and cocomplete.

fr:title.text: The subobjects of a presheaf form a Heyting algebra

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The subobjects of a presheaf form a Heyting algebra

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let C^\text {op}\xrightarrow {P} Set be a presheaf. Then the subobject poset of P is a Heyting algebra.

A Heyting algebra is a posetal bicartesian closed category. In particular, this means it has all finite meets and joins (is a lattice), along with an operation \Rightarrow , called implication, such that z\leq x\Rightarrow y\text { if and only if } z\wedge x\leq y.
A Boolean algebra is a distributive lattice in which every element x has a complement \lnot x satisfying x\wedge \lnot x = \bot \quad \text { and }\quad x\vee \lnot x = \top .

fr:title.text: Equational theory of cartesian closed categories

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Equational theory of cartesian closed categories

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In addition to those of a cartesian category, a cartesian closed category C saitsfies the following equations up to natural isomorphism:

To see the first, note that C(-, 1^x)\cong C(-\times x, 1)\cong *, and the Yoneda embedding reflects limits, so that 1^x is terminal in C. for a more abstract proof, observe that (-)^x has a right adjoint, so preserves limits.
To see the second, note that C(-, x^1)\cong C(-\times 1, x)\cong C(-, x), and representable isomorphism is isomorphism.

To see the third, note that \begin {aligned} C(-, (y\times z)^x) &\cong C(-\times x, y\times z) \\ &\cong C(-\times x, y)\times C(-\times x, z) \\ &\cong C(-, y^x)\times C(-, z^x) \\ &\cong C(-, y^x\times z^x). \end {aligned} In particular, the second step uses the representability of limits.

To see the fourth, note that \begin {aligned} C(-, x^{y\times z}) &\cong C(-, x^{z\times y}) \\ &\cong C(-\times (z\times y), x) \\ &\cong C((-\times z)\times y, x) \\ &\cong C(-\times z, x^y) \\ &\cong C(-, (x^y)^z). \end {aligned}

A global element of an object X in a cartesian closed category (or sometimes more generally a closed monoidal category, in which case the same concept is sometimes called a generalized element or state) is a morphism 1\to X.
For any category C, the category of presheaves \hat {C} is cartesian closed.

Products are computed pointwise, hence inherited from Set. By the Yoneda lemma, for c\in C an exponential Q^P, if it exists, should satisfy Q^P c \cong \hat {C}(yc, Q^P)\cong \hat {C}(yc\times P, Q). Taking this to define Q^P, we now show the desired adjunction.

Fixing some P and Q suffices to construct the evaluation natural transformation Q^P\times P\xrightarrow {\operatorname {ev}} Q (itself the Q-component of a natural transformation (-)^P\times P\to P) which induces an isomorphism on adjoint hom-sets. At c\in C, the component \operatorname {ev}_c is given a natural transformation yc\times P\xrightarrow {\phi } Q and an element p\in Pc; we define \operatorname {ev}_c(\phi , p) = \phi _c(1_c, p).

Now, it remains to show that there is a bijection \hat {C}(R, Q^P)\xrightarrow {-\times P} \hat {C}(R\times P, Q^P\times P)\xrightarrow {\operatorname {ev}_*} \hat {C}(R\times P, Q). That is, given a natural transformation R\times P\xrightarrow {\alpha } Q, we must show that there is a unique natural transformation R\xrightarrow {\beta } Q^P mapping to \alpha . At c\in C, this is a set-function Rc\xrightarrow {\beta _c} Q^Pc, where the latter is the set \hat {C}(yc\times P, Q). As such, for each element r\in Rc, we must define a natural transformation yc\times P\xrightarrow {\beta _c(r)} Q.

Let C^\text {op}\xrightarrow {P} Set be a presheaf, y\xrightarrow {f} x\in C a map, and p\in Px an element. Then the restriction of p along f, or the pullback of p along f, is p|_f = Pf(p). The restriction maps of P are just the induced set-functions Pf for each morphism f.

fr:title.text: The category of presheaves is the free cocompletion

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The category of presheaves is the free cocompletion

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Since every presheaf is a colimit of representables, hence a colimit of objects in the image of the Yoneda embedding, and the functor \hat {F} must preserve colimits, there is (up to isomorphism) only one candidate fomula: given a presheaf P, we must have \begin {aligned} \hat {F}P &= \hat {F}(\operatorname *{colim}(\text {el}(P)\xrightarrow {\Pi } C\xhookrightarrow {y} \hat {C})) \\\\ &= \operatorname *{colim} (\text {el}(P)\xrightarrow {\Pi } C\xhookrightarrow {y} \hat {C}\xrightarrow {\hat {F}} E) \\\\ &= \operatorname *{colim} (\text {el}(P) \xrightarrow {\Pi } C\xrightarrow {F} E). \end {aligned} By functoriality of colimits, this is well-defined.

By the proof of the density formula, we recognize this as the colimit formula for the Kan extension of F along y. (Indeed, since the Yoneda embedding is fully faithful, this Kan extension is necessarily an isomorphism, so that this extension necessarily makes the triangle commute.)

A sieve is a subfunctor of a contravariant hom-functor. Explicitly, a sieve S on x\in C consists of a collection of maps with codomain x that is closed under precomposition, i.e. if z\xrightarrow {f}x\in S and z'\xrightarrow {g} z is any map, then fh\in S.

A subfunctor of a [functor] C\xrightarrow {F} D is merely a subobject in the functor category D^C; this is computed pointwise, so that a subfunctor consists of a functor C\xrightarrow {G} D such that Gc\hookrightarrow Fc for each c\in C, naturally in C.

fr:title.text: Subobject classifiers are unique up to isomorphism

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Subobject classifiers are unique up to isomorphism

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Subobject classifiers are unique up to isomorphism.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Subobject classifiers represent the subobject functor and representations are unique.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The map *\xrightarrow {\top } \{0, 1\}; *\mapsto 1 is a subobject classifier in Set.

Let \hat {C} be a presheaf category. Let C^\text {op}\xrightarrow {\Omega } Set be the sieve functor, which sends an object x to the set of sieves on x, and a map y\xrightarrow {f}x to its action on sieves by restriction: (\Omega f)(S) = \{g: fg\in S\}. Let *\xhookrightarrow {\top } \Omega (where * is the constant functor at the singleton) identify for each x\in C the maximal sieve. Then \top is a subobject classifier in \hat {C}.

Let Q\hookrightarrow P be a subobject in \hat {C}. We need to define the classifying natural transformation P\xrightarrow {\chi _Q}\Omega ; we work in components. At an object x\in C, this map must send an element p\in Px to a sieve on x; we choose the sieve (\chi _Q)_x(p) = \{z\xrightarrow {f} x\in C: p|_f \in Qz\}. In other words, this sieve consists of those maps which restrict p to an element of Q.

Next, to show that it is a pullback, it suffices to show that it is a pullback at each x\in C, and by the construction of limits in Set, it suffices to show that (\chi _Q)_x(p) is the maximal sieve if and only if p\in Qx. The backwards direction is already done; conversely, if it is the maximal sieve, then we obtain the result by observing that 1_x\in (\chi _Q)_x(p) and applying the definition of \chi _Q.

Finally, to show uniqueness, suppose that we have another natural transformation P\xrightarrow {\theta } \Omega . By the above argument, for the square to be a pullback, we must have that \theta _x(p) is the maximal sieve if and only if p\in Qx. Now further, given z\xrightarrow {f} x and applying the same fact at z, we must have that p|_f\in Qz if and only if \theta _z(p|_f) is the maximal sieve. By naturality of \theta at a map f, we have that \theta _z(p|_f) = \Omega f(\theta _x(p)), which by definition of \Omega is the maximal sieve if and only if f\in \theta _x(p). As a consequence, if the square is a pullback, we must have that f\in \theta _x(p) if and only if p|_f\in Qz, yielding exactly the definition of \chi _Q above.

fr:title.text: Subobject classifiers are equivalently representations of the subobject functor

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Subobject classifiers are equivalently representations of the subobject functor

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let C be finitely complete and locally small. Then C has a subobject classifier if and only if the subobject functor is representable.

First, suppose *\xrightarrow {\top }\Omega is a subobject classifier. We claim that \Omega represents \operatorname {Sub}_C. Indeed, the assignment (s\hookrightarrow x)\xmapsto {\chi } x\xrightarrow {\chi _s} \Omega of a subobject to its characteristic map is a natural bijection \operatorname {Sub}(x)\to C(x, \Omega ). To demonstrate bijectivity, note that pulling back \top along a map x\xrightarrow {\chi _0} \Omega yields a subobject of x with characteristic map \chi _0; this assignment is unique by uniqueness of pullbacks.
A category C is well-powered if all its subobject posets are small.
